summary: This is an email chain from January 3, 2020, discussing an inquiry into whether video footage existed from inside Jeffrey Epstein's cell after his attempted suicide. The email references a claim by defense attorney Bruce Barket and an interview with a correctional officer, with the sender seeking confirmation from recipients about investigating the video's existence.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: He is mentioned as insisting that video was taken from inside Jeffrey Epstein's cell after the attempted suicide, though he won't disclose his basis for this belief.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to by initials 'JE' in the email, he is the inmate whose cell is the subject of the video inquiry following his attempted suicide.

connections.description: Barket is identified as a defense attorney, and the email discusses his claims regarding video evidence related to Epstein's cell, indicating he was likely acting in a legal capacity for Epstein.

events.title: Inquiry into Epstein cell video
events.description: An email discussion about whether video footage was taken from inside Jeffrey Epstein's cell after his attempted suicide, prompted by claims from defense attorney Bruce Barket and an interview with a correctional officer.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Defense attorney Bruce Barket insisted that video was taken from inside Jeffrey Epstein's cell after his attempted suicide, though he wouldn't disclose his basis for this belief.

The sender of the email spoke with SIS (Special Investigative Services) who confirmed no video existed, but then read an interview where a correctional officer stated a female lieutenant had a video camera in the cell after Epstein was removed.
The email seeks confirmation from recipients about whether they ever looked into the existence of this alleged video.
